item.title: Hawk seen on a walk
item.creator: leah
item.description: This hawk practically flew into the photographer as he was taking a walk one afternoon.
item.comment: This hawk practically flew into the photographer as he was taking a walk one afternoon. Photo: Jeff Artel, WDRS

item.title: Fermilab’s second artist in residence mixes tech and art
item.creator: leah
item.description: From WDCB 90.9, Jan. 25, 2016: Fermilab artist-in-residence Ellen Sandor is no stranger to translating science into visual media. She's worked with Jet Propulsion Laboratory and NASA to visualize the invisible. Now she'll do the same at Fermilab. Listen to this eight-minute radio piece featuring Sandor and Art Gallery curator Georgia Schwender.
item.comment: From WDCB 90.9, Jan. 25, 2016: Fermilab artist-in-residence Ellen Sandor is no stranger to translating science into visual media. She's worked with Jet Propulsion Laboratory and NASA to visualize the invisible. Now she'll do the same at Fermilab. Listen to this eight-minute radio piece featuring Sandor and Art Gallery curator Georgia Schwender.

item.title: Jan 28, noon, Fermi Society of Philosophy, Al Brunsting: “Science and God Existence,” first talk
item.creator: burov
item.description: Starting Jan 28, we’ll have a series of four talks of Al Brunsting based on his book on science and God’s existence. Details about the book and its authors are on our website https://fermisocietyofphilosophy.wordpress.com/. Everybody is welcome. Feel free to come with your lunch. Note the room: Racetrack (WH7X). Time is the same as always, 12 noon.
item.comment: Starting Jan 28, we’ll have a series of four talks of Al Brunsting based on his book on science and God’s existence. Details about the book and its authors are on our website https://fermisocietyofphilosophy.wordpress.com/ . Everybody is welcome. Feel free to come with your lunch. Note the room: Racetrack (WH7X). Time is the same as always, 12 noon.

item.title: February wellness
item.creator: jkoester
item.description: Check out February's wellness offerings, including a free Lunch and Learn session on preventing and alleviating neck pain.
item.comment:
COMPLIMENTARY WELLNESS

Lunch & Learn : Tech Neck
Are electronics a pain in the neck? Technology has improved our lives in many ways. Unfortunately, it may be a detriment to our necks. Spending two-thirds of the day with our necks angled down while we work at computers, text from phones, and play on tablets can lead to chronic neck pain,and result in a more serious long-term condition. Attend this educational workshop about common conditions caused from this repetitive stress. Learn tips to prevent the onset of pain and find relief from the pain and discomfort you might already be experiencing.

Tuesday, February 23, Curia II: 12-1 p.m. Lunch will be provided. Limited to 25. RSVP by Feb. 22 to megan.diehm@airrosti.com .

 

FITNESS CLASSES

Mat Pilates
Mondays: March 7 – April 18
Fitness Center Exercise Room: 12-12:45pm
Fee: $87 (Register by February 29)

Zumba Fitness
Thursdays: March 3 – April 28 (no class 3/31)
Fitness Center Exercise Room: noon-12:45 p.m. Fee: $50 (Register by February 25)

Zumba Toning
Tuesdays: March 1 – April 26 (no class March 29)
Fitness Center Exercise Room: noon-12:45 p.m. Fee: $50 (Register by February 23)

 

EMPLOYEE DISCOUNTS

Fermi Fridays with Chicago Steel Hockey Team
Experience Chicagoland’s only Tier 1 Junior Team on Fermilab Fridays (Jan. 29, Feb. 26, March 25, April 8) with the Chicago Steel at the Fox Valley Ice Arena in Geneva! Puck drops at 7:30 p.m. Defense Preferred Tickets are $12 ($16.75 value). Purchase discounted tickets at www.steelgroups.com and enter password Fermilab. $1.50/ticket processing fee applied to online orders. Tickets purchased on day of game are an additional $2. Contact Dave Campione 855-51-STEEL. dcampione@chicagosteelhockeyteam.com

Regal Cinema & AMC Theater Movie Tickets
$9 tickets sold in Wellness Office, WH15W.

http://wdrs.fnal.gov/wellness/convenience.html

item.title: ACA 1095-C and 1095-B mailed to employees
item.creator: debseb
item.description: Affordable Care Act (ACA) forms have been mailed to employees’ home addresses. If you receive one, be sure to keep the form, as you may be required to provide it when filing your 2015 Federal tax return.
item.comment:
Affordable Care Act (ACA) forms have been mailed to employees’ home addresses. If you receive one, be sure to keep the form, as you may be required to provide it when filing your 2015 federal tax return.

Who will receive a 1095-C?

Any full-time employees or part-time employees and enrolled in benefits will receive a 1095-C from Fermilab. The ACA requires employers to provide a statement to employees that includes information about the type of healthcare coverage offered to the employees, if any, during the prior year.

Who will receive a 1095-B?

Employees enrolled in the Blue Cross Blue Shield Blue Advantage HMO at any point during 2015 will receive a 1095-C from Fermilab with parts I and II completed. Blue Cross Blue Shield Blue Advantage HMO will send anyone enrolled in the HMO a 1095-B with only part III completed.

What action needs to be taken?

You should retain your Form for your records. You may be required to provide a copy of your Form 1095-C and Form 1095-B if you are in the HMO with your personal income tax filing. In addition, you or your tax preparer will enter information contained on your Form on your federal income tax return for 2015 to demonstrate that you satisfied the ACA’s obligation to have health insurance.

The IRS will also receive copies of your form so that it can verify the information you report on your federal income tax return about your health coverage for 2015. The 1095 form is your proof that you had the required coverage. If you are covering family members, their information will be included on your 1095.

For more information, please attend the ACA 1095 Lunch and Learn on Feb. 1 at noon in One West or review the frequently asked questions guide . The Lunch and Learn will be live streamed and recorded .

Questions? Contact the Fermilab Benefits Office ( benefitsoffice@fnal.gov ) and your question will be researched and answered within 24 hours.

item.title: Why I Love Neutrinos – Naba Mondal
item.creator: leah
item.description: Why I Love Neutrinos is a series spotlighting those mysterious, abundant, ghostly particles that are all around us. This installment features Professor Naba Mondal.
item.comment: Why I Love Neutrinos is a series spotlighting those mysterious, abundant, ghostly particles that are all around us. This installment features Professor Naba Mondal.

item.title: URA Thesis Award Competition
item.creator: lenny
item.description: Fermilab and the Universities Research Association invite submissions for the nineteenth annual URA Thesis Award competition. Nominations must be submitted to Lenny Spiegel at lenny@fnal.gov by March 18, 2016 and should include two letters supporting the merits of the thesis being nominated. At least one letter should be from a member of the thesis committee of the PhD granting institution and, for work carried out in collaboration with Fermilab scientists, at least one of the letters should come from one... More »
item.comment: Fermilab and the Universities Research Association invite submissions for the nineteenth annual URA Thesis Award competition. Nominations must be submitted to Lenny Spiegel at lenny@fnal.gov by March 18, 2016 and should include two letters supporting the merits of the thesis being nominated. At least one letter should be from a member of the thesis committee of the PhD granting institution and, for work carried out in collaboration with Fermilab scientists, at least one of the letters should come from one of those scientists. For further details consult the URA Thesis Award website at: http://www.fnal.gov/pub/forphysicists/fellowships/ura_thesis/index.html .

item.title: Geese make a neutrino topology
item.creator: leah
item.description: Did a goose-sized particle just interact with an air molecule? The geese's flying pattern as the pass over Wilson hall is reminiscent of a typical neutrino interaction topology in a neutrino detector.
item.comment: Did a goose-sized particle just interact with an air molecule? The geese’s flying pattern as the pass over Wilson hall is reminiscent of a typical neutrino interaction topology in a neutrino detector. Photo: Nitin Yadav, Indian Institute of Technology – Kandur
